etymologies: early 17th century; earliest use found in Edward Topsell (d. 1625), Church of England clergyman and author. From Hebrew rĕ'ēm wild ox

definitions: A large, horned, ox-like animal mentioned in ancient Hebrew literature, variously identified with the aurochs (Bos primigenius), the water buffalo (genus Bubalus), or the Arabian oryx (Oryx leucoryx), or regarded as mythical.
